name: Elena Park
description: Elena is a 27-year-old beginner blogger transitioning from customer support into sustainable living and mindful productivity content. She’s earnest, systems-curious, and fights perfectionism by publishing small, consistent posts each week. Elena builds a lightweight editorial workflow in Notion, drafts in Obsidian, and polishes with Grammarly, focusing on clarity over flair. She’s learning SEO fundamentals—search intent, simple keyword clustering, and internal linking—while keeping her tone approachable and evidence-backed. To grow confidence, she uses creative constraints (500-word posts, one story, one takeaway) and a public learning log that documents missteps and improvements. Analytics don’t intimidate her: she checks GA4 and Search Console monthly to track click-through rates, time on page, and which questions readers ask most. She repurposes posts into short social threads and a biweekly newsletter, and she’s exploring ethical monetization via affiliate recommendations, a beginner’s guide, and later, a cohort-based workshop. Values: curiosity, clarity, and kindness. Long-term, Elena wants a reader-first blog that helps busy people reduce waste without overwhelm, and she’s building the craft brick by brick through deliberate practice and feedback loops.
example_behaviours: Runs a Sunday 60-minute content planning session to prioritize topics by reader questions
Keeps a swipe file of great intros, headlines, and meta descriptions
Records walk-and-talk voice memos for story ideas during evening strolls
Hosts a weekly co-working hour with two other new bloggers for accountability
Performs a monthly analytics retro with simple goals: publish 4 posts, improve 1 evergreen article
Practices headline sprints: 15 headlines per post, then shortlisting five
Conducts accessibility checks (alt text, contrast, heading hierarchy) before publishing
Experiments with keyword clustering using a basic spreadsheet and color codes
Photographs local farmers markets for original blog visuals
Reads one craft article daily (Ann Handley, Content Marketing Institute) and summarizes notes
A/B tests newsletter subject lines for open-rate learning, not vanity metrics
Uses a 90-minute deep work block after breakfast for drafting or revising
Maintains a ‘draft graveyard’ to recycle unused paragraphs into future posts
Participates in monthly community feedback threads on Indie Hackers and r/blogging
